t: Judges 5
The Song of Deborah
Then*p Deborah and Barak the son of Abinoam sang on that day, saying:
“When*pn leaders lead in Israel, When*ld the people willingly offer themselves, Bless*ld the Lord!*s
“Hear,*ln O kings! Give ear, O princes! I,*ld even*i I, will sing to the Lord;*s I*ld will sing praise to the Lord*s God of Israel.
“Lord,*sln when You went out from Seir, When*ld You marched from the field of Edom, The*ld earth trembled and the heavens poured, The*ld clouds also poured water;
The*ld mountains gushed before the Lord,*s This*ld Sinai, before the Lord*s God of Israel.
“In*ln the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, In*ld the days of Jael, The*ld highways were deserted, And*ld the travelers walked along the byways.
Village*ld life ceased, it ceased in Israel, Until*ld I, Deborah, arose, Arose*ld a mother in Israel.
They*ld chose new gods; Then*ld there*i was*i war in the gates; Not*ld a shield or spear was seen among forty thousand in Israel.
My*ld heart is*i with the rulers of Israel Who*ld offered themselves willingly with the people. Bless*ld the Lord!*s
“Speak,*ln you who ride on white donkeys, Who*ld sit in judges’ attire, And*ld who walk along the road.

Far*ld from the noise of the archers, among the watering places, There*ld they shall recount the righteous acts of the Lord,*s The*ld righteous acts for*i His villagers in Israel; Then*ld the people of the Lord*s shall go down to the gates.
“Awake,*ln awake, Deborah! Awake,*ld awake, sing a song! Arise,*ld Barak, and lead your captives away, O*ld son of Abinoam!
“Then*ln the survivors came down, the people against the nobles; The*ld Lord*s came down for me against the mighty.
From*ld Ephraim were*i those whose roots were in Amalek. After*ld you, Benjamin, with your peoples, From*ld Machir rulers came down, And*ld from Zebulun those who bear the recruiter’s staff.

And*ld the princes of Issachar were*i with Deborah; As*ld Issachar, so was*i Barak Sent*ld into the valley under his command; Among*ld the divisions of Reuben There*ild were*i great resolves of heart.
Why*ld did you sit among the sheepfolds, To*ld hear the pipings for the flocks? The*ld divisions of Reuben have great searchings of heart.
Gilead*ld stayed beyond the Jordan, And*ld why did Dan remain on ships? Asher*ld continued at the seashore, And*ld stayed by his inlets.
Zebulun*ld is*i a people who*i jeopardized their lives to the point of death, Naphtali*ld also, on the heights of the battlefield.
“The*ln kings came and*i fought, Then*ld the kings of Canaan fought In*ld Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo; They*ld took no spoils of silver.
They*ld fought from the heavens; The*ld stars from their courses fought against Sisera.
The*ld torrent of Kishon swept them away, That*ld ancient torrent, the torrent of Kishon. O*ld my soul, march on in strength!
Then*ld the horses’ hooves pounded, The*ld galloping, galloping of his steeds.
‘Curse*ld Meroz,’ said the angel of the Lord,*s ‘Curse*ld its inhabitants bitterly, Because*ld they did not come to the help of the Lord,*s To*ld the help of the Lord*s against the mighty.’
“Most*ln blessed among women is Jael, The*ld wife of Heber the Kenite; Blessed*ld is she among women in tents.
He*ld asked for water, she gave milk; She*ld brought out cream in a lordly bowl.
She*ld stretched her hand to the tent peg, Her*ld right hand to the workmen’s hammer; She*ld pounded Sisera, she pierced his head, She*ld split and struck through his temple.
At*ld her feet he sank, he fell, he lay still; At*ld her feet he sank, he fell; Where*ld he sank, there he fell dead.
“The*ln mother of Sisera looked through the window, And*ld cried out through the lattice, ‘Why*ld is his chariot so*i long in coming? Why*ld tarries the clatter of his chariots?’
Her*ld wisest ladies answered her, Yes,*ld she answered herself,

‘Are*ld they not finding and dividing the spoil: To*ld every man a girl or*i two; For*ld Sisera, plunder of dyed garments, Plunder*ld of garments embroidered and dyed, Two*ld pieces of dyed embroidery for the neck of the looter?’
“Thus*ln let all Your enemies perish, O Lord!*s But*ld let*i those who love Him be*i like the sun When*ld it comes out in full strength.” So*p the land had rest for forty years.
